image.altText: The scene of a collision between the cockle train and a truck.

items.synopsis: A child is taken to hospital and other passengers suffer minor injuries after a collision between a heritage train and a truck at a level crossing south of Adelaide, emergency services say.

title.children: Child taken to hospital after heritage train and truck collide on SA rail line

image.altText: A smiling man in a navy suit holds the state budget papers. Behind him outside the window is Adelaide Oval

items.synopsis: The South Australian government will report a quarter-of-a-billion-dollar deficit in Thursday's state budget — a major reversal on the surplus that was forecast six months ago.

title.children: SA plunges into the red, as treasurer blames increased spending in key policy areas

image.altText: A split image of a smiling young woman with brown hair, a young man wearing sunnies and cap, and young blond woman hugging a dog

items.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns announces that a support fund will be co-managed by the state government and Rotary Australia, providing relief to survivors, victims and their immediate families.

title.children: NSW premier gives update on wedding bus crash tragedy, announcing $100k contribution to fund

image.altText: An aerial image of the River Murray.

items.synopsis: The Riverland's flood recovery coordinator reveals thousands of eligible property owners haven't taken up state government support for repairs, but locals say there isn't enough workers to help get the job done.

title.children: Flood affected Riverland residents urged to take up 'free' government support

image.altText: A truck on a road with the front crashed into a barrier with a dark sky

items.synopsis: A truck that crashed into a concrete barrier near Stirling caused significant delays for drivers on the South Eastern Freeway this morning.

title.children: Truck crash causes major delays on Adelaide freeway

image.altText: A smiling, middle-aged woman stands next to a macadamia tree.

items.synopsis: People love the macadamias Jan Cousins grows on her Paringa property, but she has no plan to capitalise on the market she has cornered.

title.children: Jan is the only macadamia grower in the Riverland, but she has no desire to turn a profit

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks to supporters at Trump National Golf Club Bedminster.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump faces criminal charges for the second time in as many months. Here's how his day in court unfolded.

title.children: No mugshot, no cash bond and no talking to the valet: Key takeaways from Trump's brief court appearance

image.altText: A smiling, young woman with long dark hair.

items.synopsis: Simone Strobel's naked body was found in Lismore in 2005. Last year Tobias Moran was charged over her death, but today prosecutors have withdrawn their case.

title.children: Charges dropped against man accused of cold case murder of German backpacker Simone Strobel

image.altText: A middle aged woman looks at documents  at her kitchen table

items.synopsis: Elisabetta Di Nardo has been battling with ANZ for almost two years for lending her money she says was based on inaccurate information provided without her knowledge.

title.children: Elisabetta says ANZ failed to verify her home loan application, now she's taking legal action

image.altText: A man in a NT Police uniform standing at a lectern inside a room, looking exasperated.

items.synopsis: Jamie Chalker left his role as Commissioner of NT Police in April. Now, it's been revealed that his payout could hit his former force's bottom line.

title.children: Former NT police commissioner's payout to impact police budget, treasurer reveals

image.altText: An unidentifiable man in suit in a high rise office, photographed from behind.

items.synopsis: While a 5.75 per cent increase in award wages attracts widespread criticism, a new report reveals the nation's big business leaders are receiving an average 15 per cent base pay rise.

title.children: How much does your big boss get paid? These figures might give you a fair idea

image.altText: An illustration of two spiked lizards on rocks, one lizard has its mouth open with a visible navy blue tongue sticking out.

items.synopsis: Its official name is Tiliqua frangens, but its bulky bod and serious spiky armour mean it already has a range of colourful nicknames including "Mega Chonk" and "Chonkasaurus".

title.children: Giant prehistoric skink dubbed 'Mega Chonk' discovered in Dubbo region

image.altText: Vladimir Putin points his right ring finger upwards as he sits at a table near a mic.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin spends more than two hours giving some of his most detailed remarks about Russia's invasion of Ukraine in months, as the first independent confirmation of the results of Kyiv's counteroffensive come through from the frontlines.

title.children: Putin spends hours speaking on Ukraine war as division between Wagner and defence ministry deepens

image.altText: A photo of a middle aged woman with blond hair and glasses in a white corridor

items.synopsis: Vanessa says it wasn't until her son was in a critical condition that he was admitted to hospital for treatment of his eating disorder. She says families need more support to manage the condition at home.

title.children: 'We've been told he won't die today. Go home': Mum's plea for more home-based eating disorder support

image.altText: a young brunette woman smiling into the camera

items.synopsis: JM Lane had been living in Canada since early January and was on a road trip in British Columbia before she was due to start a finance job.

title.children: Canadian police find Brisbane woman's body while searching remote hiking trail

image.altText: Jennie and Ray give smile deeply at each other in an open-top car. They are in wedding dress and suit.

items.synopsis: A scrap of clothing found by a member of the public has prompted police to re-examine a mine shaft where the body of amateur prospector Ray Kehlet— whose wife remains missing — was found eight years ago.

title.children: Scrap of clothing in mine shaft prompts fresh search eight years after prospector's body found

image.altText: A close up image of recycled cardboard

items.synopsis: Australia has a long way to go to becoming one of the world's great recycling nations. Here's what we could learn from other countries.

title.children: 'Pay as you throw': What Australia could learn from some of the world's best recyclers

image.altText: An Indigenous flag flaps in the wind against a blue sky background

items.synopsis: The group is under pressure to take control of the campaign for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.

title.children: Yes23 campaign under pressure as final vote legislation looms

image.altText: A woman lying in bed with medications next to her

items.synopsis: COVID-19, the flu and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are together driving a wave of respiratory illnesses. But how do I know which one I might have?

title.children: Heard of the triple-threat this winter? How to tell if you have the flu, COVID or RSV

image.altText: Sunlight enters Tam Pa Ling cave's steep entrance

items.synopsis: Bone fragments found in a mountain cave in northern Laos are the oldest evidence of modern humans in South-East Asia, suggesting our species was in the region much earlier than previously thought, say scientists.

title.children: Ancestors or a 'failed migration'? Researchers find ancient human fossils in mainland South-East Asia

image.altText: A woman works at a desk with three screens.

items.synopsis: Of all the things Australians can do to boost productivity, working harder is one of the least likely to make a difference, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Don't blame workers for falling productivity – we're not the ones holding it back

image.altText: A pile of US bank notes

items.synopsis: Investor optimism that the US Federal Reserve will keep rates on hold this week drives stocks higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US interest rate pause expected as inflation slows, ASX gains

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Department store David Jones has issued a statement, after The Australian published leaked sales figures, showing a double-digit sales drop off in some stores. The sales figures cover last week's trade and show a total drop of 10 per cent, with mixed fortunes across stores — one regional store had seen sales down close to 30 per cent from a year ago, according to The Australian. "Continued rate rises are likely to have some impact on consumer confidence across the retail sector, until rates start to come down," a David Jones spokesperson told the ABC. The retailer also said it's "not looking to compete with all the sales in the market" given its "premium" offering. Shares in listed department store rival Myer are down 2 per cent in afternoon trade, while other retailers a mixed, with Super Retail (-0.5%) and Premier Investments (-0.5%) lower but Harvey Norman (+0.9%) and Adairs (+0.7%) on the rise.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate rises will continue to impact consumer confidence: David Jones

children.content: after The Australian published leaked sales figures
, showing a double-digit sales drop off in some stores.

"Continued rate rises are likely to have some impact on consumer confidence across the retail sector, until rates start to come down," a David Jones spokesperson told the ABC.
The retailer also said it's "not looking to compete with all the sales in the market" given its "premium" offering.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Council of Financial Regulators has backed the banking watchdog's 3 per cent buffer for assessing whether borrowers can repay a home loan. APRA requires the banks to add 3 per cent on top of current rates when carrying out a serviceability assessment on customers taking out or refinancing a loan. That's to make sure borrowers can still make their repayments even if interest rates rise, and with the cash rate now 4 per cent above where it was last April, borrowers assessed during the low rate period are now potentially paying rates well above the buffer. Given variable rates are pushing up over 3 per cent, borrowers are being assessed on their ability to repay with rates over 9 per cent — making it a much steeper hurdle to clear and limiting the options many have. At its quarterly meeting, the Council — which includes members from the RBA, ASIC, APRA and Treasury —said it would continue to closely monitor how lenders are supporting customers experiencing financial hardship, as households experience increased pressure. The Council recognised that some borrowers were facing challenges in refinancing their existing loan with another lender because of a range of difficulties, including in meeting the serviceability criteria that lenders use. APRA's prudential framework does not prohibit banks from lending to these borrowers, although APRA expects that banks will set prudent limits for their exceptions to lending policy and monitor such lending closely. Council members supported APRA's assessment that the serviceability buffer — currently set at 3 per cent — remains at the appropriate level given the current environment, including the high degree of uncertainty and risks to the economic outlook. The Council noted that APRA would continue to assess the appropriateness of macroprudential policy settings as economic and financial conditions evolve.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Financial regulators back 3% home loan assessment buffer

children.content: The Council of Financial Regulators has backed the banking watchdog's 3 per cent buffer for assessing whether borrowers can repay a home loan.
APRA requires the banks to add 3 per cent on top of current rates when carrying out a serviceability assessment on customers taking out or refinancing a loan.

That's to make sure borrowers can still make their repayments even if interest rates rise, and with the cash rate now 4 per cent above where it was last April, borrowers assessed during the low rate period are now potentially paying rates well above the buffer.

Given variable rates are pushing up over 3 per cent, borrowers are being assessed on their ability to repay with rates over 9 per cent — making it a much steeper hurdle to clear and limiting the options many have.
At its quarterly meeting, the Council —

which includes members from the RBA, ASIC, APRA and Treasury —said it would continue to closely monitor how lenders are supporting customers experiencing financial hardship, as households experience increased pressure.

The Council recognised that some borrowers were facing challenges in refinancing their existing loan with another lender because of a range of difficulties, including in meeting the serviceability criteria that lenders use.

APRA's prudential framework does not prohibit banks from lending to these borrowers, although APRA expects that banks will set prudent limits for their exceptions to lending policy and monitor such lending closely.

Council members supported APRA's assessment that the serviceability buffer — currently set at 3 per cent — remains at the appropriate level given the current environment, including the high degree of uncertainty and risks to the economic outlook.
The Council noted that APRA would continue to assess the appropriateness of macroprudential policy settings as economic and financial conditions evolve.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market remains in positive territory at lunchtime, but falls in the health care sector are capping the gains. A strong session for the major miners has helped push the ASX 200 and the All Ordinaries up around 0.2 per cent. There's some standout gains from BHP (+3%), Rio Tinto (+3%) and Fortescue (+4%). On the flipside, CSL is down 7.6 per cent, making it the worst-performer among the top 200 stocks and dragging down the health care sector. Here are the best and worst performers on the ASX 200 so far, with resources stocks dominating the gains. Top 5: Allkem (+4.2%) IGO (+4.1%) Fortescue (+4%) Pilbara Minerals (+3.9%) Liontown Resources (+3.8%) Bottom 5: CSL (-7.6%) Capricorn Metals (-5.4%) Bellevue Gold (-4%) Paladin Energy (-4%) Auckland Intl Airport (-2.8%)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX higher but health care weighing

children.content: The local share market remains in positive territory at lunchtime, but falls in the health care sector are capping the gains.

image.altText: dark-haired woman sits on some steps, cuddling her young, fair-haired daughter.

items.synopsis: When electrician Erin Bohanna moved to Gladstone with her family she already had work lined up. But after trying to secure day care for her daughter, she realised she would not be able to take the position.

title.children: Tradie mum turns down dream job after being placed 110th on childcare waitlist

image.altText: A woman of Asian heritage holding a microphone and speaking on stage.

items.synopsis: Jocelyn Chia, a New York-based comedian, stirred controversy in Malaysia and Singapore after she posted on social media a clip of her live comedy set in which she joked about the plane that went missing nine years ago with 239 people onboard.

title.children: 'Some jokes don't land': Comedian investigated over missing flight MH370 joke

image.altText: The external prison with construction work underway

items.synopsis: The NSW Public Service Association wants the NSW Minister for Corrections to lower entry requirements and offer more incentives to attract new people into the profession.

title.children: Prison staff punched, bitten, spat on due to chronic shortages, union says

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus smiles on the lane rope

items.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus will head for the world championships as underdog, but wonders how new record-holder Summer McIntosh will handle the pressure in their showdown.

title.children: Ariarne Titmus ready to 'pounce' on world record holder Summer McIntosh

image.altText: An AFL player eyes the football he holds in one hand as he prepares to kick.

items.synopsis: James Sicily is suspended for three weeks for a tackle on Hugh McCluggage, as Hawthorn attempted to use a doctor to explain another Hawk was to blame for the incident.

title.children: Hawks captain banned over tackle despite club's attempts to place blame on another player

image.altText: A large white grain silo.

items.synopsis: Two agribusiness conglomerates, Bunge and Viterra, have agreed to merge — a decision that's likely to prompt close scrutiny from Australia's competition watchdog.

title.children: Global grain giants Bunge and Viterra agree to $34 billion merger

image.altText: Brittany Higgins walking alongside another woman, with a man walking behind her.

items.synopsis: The conversation in federal parliament before winter break is who knows what about a sexual assault allegation made by former Liberal staffer Brittany Higgins in 2021.

title.children: Support services warn parliament, media that Brittany Higgins is being used as a 'political football'

image.altText: Cormac McCarthy

items.synopsis: Fellow American author Stephen King has remembered McCarthy as "maybe the greatest American novelist of my time".

title.children: Cormac McCarthy, celebrated author of No Country for Old Men and The Road, dies at 89

image.altText: Badiucao in front of artwork, which depicts Chinese official and smaller art work pieces on the floor, wearing masks.

items.synopsis: The Chinese government is attempting to shut down an exhibition in Poland showing works by Chinese-Australian artist Badiucao, which an official says "hurt Chinese people's feelings".

title.children: Artist calls on Australia for help in 'very absurd' attempt from Chinese government to stop his exhibition
